prompt: Outcome-based quarterly prioritization across three competing initiatives (design system rebuild, checkout performance, speculative AI widget)

options.text: Use a lightweight portfolio process: RICE or cost-of-delay scoring, enforce WIP limits, set UX guardrails (p75 LCP/INP/error rate) per initiative, and pre-define kill criteria for the AI bet
Take the HiPPO choice; largest stakeholder decides to “align” the org
Greenlight all three in parallel to keep everyone happy
Pick whatever demos best for the board; velocity optics beat impact

explanation: Portfolio process: Scoring + WIP limits focuses capacity on highest impact, guardrails protect UX, and explicit kill criteria prevent sunk-cost on speculative bets.
explanationIncorrect: HiPPO bias: Stakeholder preference is not a proxy for impact and invites politicized prioritization.
No WIP limits: Starting everything creates thrash and lowers throughput.
Demo optics: Favoring flashy demos over outcomes leads to poor ROI and brittle incentives.
source: RICE / cost-of-delay methods; SRE Workbook (guardrails); Accelerate (DORA) on flow efficiency

options.text: Publish an outcome-based roadmap with “bets” sized by confidence; tie to north-star metrics and leading indicators; revisit quarterly
Commit to fixed scope and dates for all quarters to create certainty
Replace the roadmap with OKRs only; outcomes will emerge
Track vanity metrics (pageviews, followers) to show progress

explanation: Outcome bets: Confidence-banded bets aligned to north-star metrics keep direction clear while preserving agility; quarterly revisits adapt to learning.
explanationIncorrect: Rigid scope: Ignores uncertainty and increases failure risk.
OKRs only: Lacks sequencing and cross-team coordination signal.
Vanity metrics: Do not reflect user or business value.
source: Product roadmapping best practices; North Star framework; OKR literature

prompt: Design system adoption is stalling across product teams

options.text: Treat platform as a product: versioned contracts, SLAs, published roadmap; embed a DS engineer with key teams; measure adoption/TTM and defect reduction
Centralize as gatekeepers and block merges using non-approved components
Mandate a big-bang migration this quarter
Keep DS as a passive library; allow forks for speed

explanation: Platform-as-a-product: Clear contracts, embedded support, and outcome metrics reduce friction and align incentives for adoption.
explanationIncorrect: Gatekeeping: Encourages workarounds and erodes trust.
Big-bang mandate: High risk and likely to stall delivery.
Passive library/forks: Leads to fragmentation and drift.
source: Team Topologies (platform as a product); design system adoption case studies

prompt: Frontend outage caused by a misconfigured feature flag

options.text: Run a blameless postmortem: timeline, contributing factors, user impact; create action items with owners/dates; add a pre-flight checklist to rollout playbooks
Identify who flipped the wrong flag and require their changes to be approved going forward
Skip the postmortem; ship a hotfix and move on
Focus the doc on who was paged and how long; skip systemic causes

explanation: Blameless learning: Systemic analysis plus concrete actions (e.g., checklists, validation) reduces recurrence and speeds future mitigation.
explanationIncorrect: Individual blame: Masks systemic issues and discourages reporting.
No postmortem: Loses learning and repeats failures.
Pager metrics only: Omits root causes and prevention.
source: Google SRE Book/Workbook (postmortems); progressive delivery patterns

prompt: Risk-managed rollouts for a high-impact checkout change

options.text: Progressive delivery 1%→5%→25%→50%→100% with automatic rollback on guardrail breach; emit variant in telemetry
Roll to 100% immediately to maximize learning
Hide behind a client-only flag with no server safeguards
Ignore heterogeneity; a single global effect is enough

explanation: Staged ramps: Gradual exposure with guardrails and attribution minimizes blast radius and accelerates safe decisions.
explanationIncorrect: Big-bang: Maximizes risk and recovery cost.
Client-only flag: Lacks backend protections for rollback/safety.
Ignore cohorts: Masks harm to specific devices/regions.
source: Progressive delivery practices; SRE change management

prompt: Executive communication when a critical date will be missed

options.text: Communicate early with impact, options, and a recommit plan; show trade-offs (scope, resources, timeline) and guardrail risk; ask for a decision
Delay the message until you have a perfect plan; reduce noise
Overpromise a new aggressive date to recover trust
Blame upstream teams and ask leadership to intervene

explanation: Early options: Clear impact and choices enable informed trade-offs and preserve trust with leadership.
explanationIncorrect: Delay: Surprises leadership and compresses options.
Overpromise: Erodes credibility when missed again.
Blame: Increases conflict without reducing risk.
source: Executive communication best practices; risk management literature

options.text: Gate merges on risk-weighted metrics: p75 Web Vitals regression, per-route JS transfer/execute budgets, change-affected coverage floors, and sample mutation testing
Require 100% global coverage for all files
Use Lighthouse score ≥ 90 as the sole KPI
Rely on manual QA sign-off for every change

explanation: Risk-weighted gates: Focus on user-perceived performance and changed surfaces to keep flow while catching impactful regressions.
explanationIncorrect: 100% coverage: Incentivizes shallow tests and slows delivery.
Single KPI: Composite scores can be gamed and lack signal.
Manual sign-off: Doesn’t scale and delays feedback loops.
source: web.dev (performance budgets, Core Web Vitals); Stryker (mutation testing)

options.text: Track adoption (% of UIs using DS primitives), time-to-ship deltas, defect rate in shared components, and cross-platform consistency
Count total components in the library and Storybook pages
Measure PRs opened by the DS team
Use weekly blog posts as the main success artifact

explanation: Outcome metrics: Adoption, speed, quality, and consistency tie DS effort to product impact.
explanationIncorrect: Component counts: Quantity does not equal value.
PR activity: Measures effort, not outcomes.
Blogs: Communication ≠ adoption or quality improvements.
source: Design system metrics case studies; outcome-based product metrics

prompt: Hiring signals: Senior vs. Staff Frontend (IC)

options.text: Senior: consistently delivers complex features end-to-end, raises quality bars locally, owns a domain; Staff: sets cross-team strategy, designs systems, multiplies others, leads ambiguous initiatives
Use years of experience as the primary signal
Use GitHub stars and conference talks as the primary signal
People management is required for Staff IC

explanation: Scope and impact: Senior vs. Staff IC is differentiated by breadth, ambiguity handling, and org-level influence—not tenure.
explanationIncorrect: Years: Weak proxy for capability and scope.
Stars/talks: Popularity signals don’t equal execution impact.
Management: Staff IC is an individual-contributor track.
source: Industry leveling frameworks (IC tracks); engineering career ladders

prompt: Growing a mid-level engineer into Senior

options.text: Define outcome goals, assign a scoped stretch project with a safety net, schedule regular feedback, and pair on design and trade-offs
Micro-manage tasks and review only code style
Send to a week-long course and expect immediate Senior performance
Throw them into a critical project alone to “see if they swim”

explanation: Deliberate practice: Structured stretch work with coaching and feedback builds Senior behaviors reliably.
explanationIncorrect: Micromanagement: Stifles growth and autonomy.
Training-only: Courses don’t translate to immediate behavior change.
Sink-or-swim: High risk with poor learning environment.
source: Coaching/mentorship literature; engineering management best practices

prompt: Decision making under reversibility (two-way vs one-way doors)

options.text: Treat reversible (two-way) decisions as fast/cheap experiments; reserve heavier rigor for one-way doors; bias to action with safe-to-fail guards
Treat all decisions as one-way and require consensus
Delay decisions until perfect information is available
Always A/B test everything regardless of cost and ethics

explanation: Two-way doors: Move fast on reversible choices; invest rigor where reversibility is low to manage irreversible risk.
explanationIncorrect: One-way everywhere: Slows learning and delivery.
Perfect information: Rare in practice; delays compound risk.
Test everything: Impractical, costly, and sometimes unethical.
source: Reversible/irreversible decisions (Bezos memo); decision theory basics

prompt: Privacy by design in product planning

options.text: Apply data minimization, purpose limitation, DPIA where needed; gate non-essential tracking behind consent; log proof of consent and enable easy revocation
Collect everything by default and sort it out later
Defer privacy review until after launch
Use dark patterns to increase opt-ins

explanation: Privacy by design: Minimize data, align to stated purposes, assess risks (DPIA), and enforce consent with revocation to reduce legal and trust risk.
explanationIncorrect: Collect-first: Creates regulatory and reputational exposure.
Late review: Expensive rework and compliance risk.
Dark patterns: Non-compliant and damages user trust.
source: GDPR principles; EDPB guidance; privacy-by-design best practices
